Mrs. Yarileen Valiente, Primary Emergency Coordinator, should be contacted first. In case she is not available, the following person in the list should be addressed. In any case, the order of the persons appearing on the list will be strictly followed for this notification process until someone is reached. The Primary Emergency Coordinator and alternates shall have complete authority to commit company resources in the event of an emergency.

The Contingency Plan will be implemented in the following situations:

¿	Fire and/or Explosion
¿	Spills or Release of Materials

Upon observation of the situation that will require the plan to be implemented, the person making the discovery shall immediately, only if within his or her capabilities, perform the tasks outlined in the standard operating procedure:

¿	Proceed to evaluate the incident for fire and/or explosion, safety and health hazards.
¿	If the incident is due to a spill, if possible, stop the flow of the material (only trained personnel).
¿	Immediately notify the Emergency Coordinators.

In the event of an imminent or actual emergency situation, the Emergency Coordinator will be notified first; subsequently, all emergency response personnel, appropriate agencies, and if their help is needed, civil defense, fire or police departments will also be notified. Authorization to contact regulatory agencies regarding any spill will be limited to the Primary Emergency Coordinator, who must be contacted as soon as possible.

Once a designated Emergency Coordinator has been notified, he or she will initiate the response efforts only if these are within the response capabilities of the response team. The Emergency Coordinator or person in charge will immediately identify the character, exact source, amount and extent of the release. The initial identification will be performed by

visual inspection of the material and location of the release. For this purpose, all materials must always be properly identified and labeled and its location shall always be the same. The Emergency Coordinator will assess possible hazards, both direct and indirect to human health or the environment that may result from the release, fire or explosion. 

In the event a facility evacuation is imminent, the following actions will be taken:

¿	The warning for evacuation will be activated.
¿	Gates will be opened immediately. No further entry to visitors, contractors, or trucks will be permitted. All vehicle traffic within the facilities will cease to allow safe exit of personnel and movement of emergency equipment.
¿	All personnel, visitors, and contractors will immediately leave through the exit gate and proceed to assigned rally points.
¿	No person shall remain in or reenter the location unless specifically authorized by the person or persons calling for the evacuation. In allowing this, the person in charge assumes the responsibility for those persons within the perimeter. Those within the fenced area will normally include Emergency Response Team personnel or emergency teams.
¿	All persons will be accounted for by their immediate supervisors. Supervisors will designate the safest exits for their employees and will also choose alternate exits in case the first choice is inaccessible. 
¿	During exit, the supervisor should try to keep his or her group together. Immediately upon exit through the gate, the highest ranking supervisor will prepare a list of all personnel at the exit gate. All other personnel who have persons reporting to them should report immediately to the front gate for final accounting.
¿	Upon completion of the employee list, the supervisor in charge will hand carry the list to the Emergency Coordinator. All other personnel will remain at their assigned rally point area.
¿	Contractors' personnel should also be listed with the name of their co

mpany.
¿	The names of Emergency Response team and or other emergency team members involved in the emergency response efforts will be reported, in writing, to the front gate by designated response team personnel.
¿	A final tally of persons will be made by the Emergency Coordinator.
¿	No attempt to find persons not accounted for will involve endangering lives of others by reentry into emergency areas.
¿	Reentry into the fenced area will be made only after clearance is given by the Emergency Coordinator. At his/her direction, a signal or other notification will be given for reentry into the facility.
¿	In all questions of accountability, immediate supervisors will be held responsible for those persons reporting to them. Visitors will be the responsibility of those employees they are seeing. Contractors are the responsibility of those persons administering the individual contracts. Truck drivers are the responsibility of the warehouse supervisor or the area supervisor.
¿	Drills will be held to practice all of these procedures and will be treated with the same seriousness as an actual emergency.

All injured persons will be removed, and medical treatment will be administered by qualified personnel (First Aid and/or CPR can only be administered by certified individuals). Because fire is always a potential hazard in spills of flammable materials, possible sources of ignition will be eliminated. Vehicular traffic and hazardous work in the area will cease until the spill is contained and safety is restored. If spilled materials are flammable, the Emergency Response Team will mobilize with foam equipment and hoses. Flushing with large quantities of water or foaming will be performed only if advised by the Emergency Coordinator. If a highly flammable material (flammable gas) is released, all persons within at least a quarter mile radius from the facility will be notified. he safety of the personnel at the scene of a release of hazardous materials is critical to consider before any action is taken. All release of materials should be considered initially as extremely hazardous until the identity of the spilled material is known. 

The following guidelines are followed as part of the initial response:

¿	Use of Level B PPE (SCBA or supplied airline respirators) is mandatory for the initial entry. After atmospheric hazard evaluation is completed, lower PPE's could be selected but only as indicated by the Emergency Coordinator in charge.
¿	The use of the buddy system (work in pairs) is also mandatory.
¿	Approach the spill from its upwind side.
¿	Do not touch the material and avoid any direct or indirect contact with it.
¿	Remove all possible ignition sources from the immediate area.
¿	Do not allow smoking in the area.
¿	Limit the access to the area to response personnel only.
¿	Do not touch any container, tank or material unless full knowledge of the hazards involved is available.

A decontamination area will be established near any release area. Any decontamination procedure must be carried out at an area properly isolated by impervious materials. In order to avoid cross contamination during the cleaning process, the area being decontaminated will be isolated. Once clean-up is completed, material will be collected and disposed of properly. Prior to leaving a hazardous material release location undergoing decontamination, decontamination of personal protective clothing will be conducted and all outside protective clothing materials as well as exposed skin surfaces. All personnel involved in the clean-up operations will be thoroughly clean-up by spraying, washing and scrubbing with a soft bristle, non-metallic brush, a mild detergent solution, and rinse three times all outside protective clothing materials as well as exposed skin surfaces at the decontamination area prior to departure from the site. All rinse waters and person

erson to issue the notification, and if their help is needed, civil defense, fire or police departments will also be notified.

The material should be contained immediately to prevent it from reaching areas such as water supply systems, sewers and private property. After containment, the material will be cleaned up (only trained personnel) and disposed of properly. Primary responsibility for supervision of control, containment and clean-up rests with the highest ranking company employee on site, until properly relieved of control, either by the Emergency Coordinator, a company official or a responsible agency official or duly appointed on-scene coordinator. During any incident, the chain of command must be followed in the form of the Incident Command System (ICS).

Once the necessary information has been collected, the communication of the spill to the responsible agencies will be initiated, if applicable and only by personnel authorized to perform these duties. If the spill or incident is beyond the capabilities of the internal response team, then the Emergency Coordinator will order evacuation of the premises if necessary and will contact a trained emergency response agency or, qualified HAZMAT contractor.

The Puerto Rico Environmental Quality Board and the National Response Center will be notified whenever one of the following situations occur:

¿	A spill discharges to a surface water and the quantity of hazardous material is equal to or greater than the Reportable Quantity specified under 40 CFR Part 117.
¿	One thousand gallons or more of oil are spilled in a single event. If a lesser quantity has been spilled, but has entered a storm sewer, it is advisable to contact local authorities for assistance or if it is not possible to intercept the spill at the outfall or prevent the oil slick from moving.
¿	The spill involves other hazardous materials not listed but used at the facilities, if they pose an actual or potential hazard to life or property.

Should any pump and/or line be used for transfer of liquids to shipping containers it must be dismantled, drained and scrubbed with a hard bristle non-metallic brush suitable for the determined atmospheric hazard, washed with detergent, steam cleaned and tripled rinsed with water.

After the decontamination process is completed, each decontaminated unit or equipment will be rinsed with water for a final time. The wash water must be collected in appropriate containers for later disposal. After this is performed, each unit will be tagged as ready for later use.

Flexitank maintains an excellent relationship with the local authorities. In the event of an emergency, Flexitank will initiate an evacuation of the facility and notify the proper authorities. Employees are trained to evacuate their respective areas in accordance with OSHA 1910.38(a). Flexitank's Process Safety Management (PSM) program follows the requirements set forth in 29 CFR 1910.119. It also complies with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. It includes, but it is not limited to the following:

Executive Summary
EPA Risk Management Program Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Flexitank, Inc. is a privately held logistics company, located in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico, committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes related to bulk chemical transportation and storage in a safe and responsible manner in compliance with applicable federal, state and local regulations. Flexitank has implemented a safety and security program in which training to personnel in the operation, hazardous materials handling and warehouse safety is included. All Flexitank employees are informed of hazards in the workplace, are trained accordingly and have procedures in place on the facility in the unlikely event that hazardous substance releases were to occur, which activates emergency notification and response procedures to ensure the safety of our employees, the community, the environment and property. 

2. Facility and Regulated Substances

Flexitank is an NVOCC (OTI) that specializes in logistics management. We occasionally store ISO-tanks containing chemical products for our customers as an added value service in our Depot Facilities located on the Zona Portuaria in San Juan. 

Flexitank Depot receives the bulk liquid cargo by the following modes of transportation: tank trucks, ISO tank containers and flexi-bags (no hazardous products only). The received cargo is stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and it is subsequently dispatch on the same transportation modes as originally received. Flexitank, Inc. does not perform any chemical processing, manufacturing or product transfer to intermediate storage containers. 

The following Regulated Toxic Substances are occasionally stored at Flexitank, Depot facilities and have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release: 

Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS Number 7664

-41-7)

Our Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) which includes, but are not limited to; Emergency response and contingency plans and training programs, in combination with our on-site emergency response HAZMAT team help us effectively manage and minimized the potential hazards posed to our employees, the community, and the environment. 

3. Prevention Program

Actions to prevent the recurrence or spread of fires, explosions or releases include stopping processes and operations, collecting and containing released material, and recovering or isolating containers. In addition, if the facility stops operations in response to an emergency, the Emergency Coordinator will monitor valves, pipes and other equipment for leaks, pressure build up, gas generation or ruptures.

The information contained in this program has been prepared in accordance with the requirements for a Prevention, Preparedness and Contingency Plan as set forth in 40 CFR Parts 265.50 through 265.56, as well as any applicable Commonwealth of Puerto Rico laws, rules and regulations. Also, elements of Emergency Response Plans (in accordance to EPCRA requirements), and of Risk Management Plans (40 CFR 63) have been incorporated to minimize hazards to human health or the environment resulting from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials or any of its constituents to the air, soil or surface water.

The hazardous materials storage facilities are inspected on a weekly basis. The inspection forms include a written checklist to be followed during the inspection. The facilities are inspected for signs posted, safety features, liquid level, tank or container identification, ruptures, corrosion, leaks, conditions of vents, integrity of dikes, materials inside dikes and other. Any deficiency is immediately reported and corrective action taken as soon as possible. Records are maintained until the next internal inspection is conducted or five years, whichever i

s longest.

All fire extinguishers must comply with National Fire Code Standards for portable fire extinguisher, and they are inspected after each use or at least once every month. Equipment for use in containing and cleaning up spilled hazardous materials are inspected after each use, or at least once every week. Records of these inspections are kept for at least three years.

Prior to any company employee being assigned to handling hazardous materials, he or she must be instructed by qualified resources, on the hazards of the material, safety and health precautions, and the use and requirements for protective clothing and equipment, including respirators. Any operational personnel that will be involved in any way in the response to an incident involving hazardous materials, waste or substances must receive the appropriate training.

The following trainings are taken by the appropriate personnel:

¿	24 hour Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (First Responder Operations Level Course) - Personnel that will help in the control of the incident but that will not apply defensive measures to control the spill.
¿	40 hour Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazardous Materials Technician Course) - Personnel that will actually become in contact with the spilled material and that will employ defensive strategies in order to stop the release. The Emergency Coordinators have at least this course level.
¿	Fire Fighting Training - Employees that are part of the fire brigade or firefighting team.
¿	CPR and First Aid - Recommended for all employees involved in the response to an incident.
¿	8 hour HAZWOPER Refresher - All employees that are part of the Emergency Response Team comply with the yearly continuing education requirement as established by OSHA.

3. Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios

Flexitank performs a worst-case release scenario analysis to identify the potential reach and effect of hypothetical worst-case acci

dental release for each toxic and flammable substance held above the applicable threshold quantity in the process, that if released under worst-case conditions, would potentially effect the largest geographical area around the facility and public receptors.

Also, Flexitank performs alternative release scenario analysis to identify the potential reach and effect of hypothetical accidental releases under more realistic circumstances, and identify and analyze reasonable release scenarios that are more likely to occur than worst-case release scenarios and that reach an off-site endpoint.

4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Ammonia Specific Prevention

Flexitank, Inc. has programs to ensure proper operation and maintenance of the ammonia ISO-tanks. ISO-tanks are considered portable tanks; they are designed and constructed by IMO and 49 CFR 172.101 T, codes and industry standards. Regulatory inspections of these tanks are performed accordingly, and a pre-trip preventive maintenance program is in place to ensure ongoing system integrity and to minimize release incidents. All employees associated with this facility operation have been trained and are knowledgeable in the safe operation of ISO tanks and emergency response procedures in case of a release. 

5. Five Year Accident History

During the past five (5) years, there have been no accidental releases from RMP covered processes at the Flexitank Depot or off site which resulted in death, injuries, or significant property or environmental damages.

All incidents and releases, on site or off site, are formally investigated as part of our facility's QHSSE program to identify corrective and preventive actions for continuous process improvement.
